question: Question 6-05/30/2012 Which ONE of the following is the most correct reason for having an installed neutron source within the core? An installed neutron source is very important during startup because without of a neutron source...

answers.answer: a. the chain reaction in the reactor core would NOT start
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.4

answers.answer: b. the startup channel would NEVER indicate neutron population
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.4

answers.answer: c. the compensating voltage on the source range detector doesn’t work
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.4

answers.answer: d. the reactor could result in a sudden increase in power if the control rods were pulled out far enough
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 9-05/30/2012 In a just critical reactor, the reactor operator immediately inserts a rabbit of $0.50 reactivity worth into the core. This insertion will cause: Given: T: reactor period, l*: Prompt neutron lifetime; ρ: reactivity insertion; β: beta fraction

answers.answer: a. A sudden drop in delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: b. A number of prompt neutrons equals to a number of delayed neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: c. The resultant period to be a function of the prompt neutron lifetime (T=l*/ρ)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Burn, R., Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, © 1988, Sec 4.6, page 4-17

answers.answer: d. A sudden change of power that equals to the initial power multiplied by β(1- ρ)/ (β -ρ)
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 10-05/30/2012 Which ONE of the following is a correct statement of why delayed neutrons enhance the ability to control reactor power?

answers.answer: a. Prompt neutrons can cause fissions in both U-235 and U-238; where as delayed neutrons can only cause fissions in U-235
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.6

answers.answer: b. The average number of delayed neutrons produced per fission is higher than the average number of prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.6

answers.answer: c. Delayed neutrons are born at higher energy levels than prompt neutrons
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Section 9.6

answers.answer: d. Delayed neutrons increase the average neutron lifetime that allows a reactor to be controlled
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 11-05/30/2012 TRIGA reactor fuel has a unique feature known as the prompt negative temperature coefficient (PNTC). Which ONE of the following is the MAJOR contributor of the PNTC?

answers.answer: a. As the fuel heats up, the resonance absorption peaks broaden and increases the likelihood of absorption in U-238 and/or Pu-240.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Section 10.6

answers.answer: b. As the fuel heats up, a moderator temperature increase reduces the non-leakage and resonance escape probability.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Section 10.6

answers.answer: c. As the fuel heats up, fission product poisons (e.g., Xe) increase in concentration within the fuel matrix and add negative reactivity via neutron absorption.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REF: Reed Training Manual, Section 10.6

answers.answer: As the fuel heats up, the oscillating hydrogen atoms in the ZrH have more energy than the thermal neutrons, thus they transfers energy to the thermal neutrons, cause the thermal neutron to leave the fuel without fissions.
answers.feedback: Correct

question: Question 12-05/30/2012 Which ONE of the following statements correctly describes thermal neutrons?

answers.answer: a. A neutron that experiences a linear decrease in energy as the temperature of the moderator increases.
b. A neutron at resonant epithermal energy levels that causes fissions to occur in U-238.
c. A neutron that experiences an increase in energy levels after collisions with larger atoms of the moderator.
d. A neutron that experiences no net change in energy after several collisions with atoms of the moderator.
answers.feedback: Correct
